results.headline: Hard Knocks, Both Given and Gotten

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wrestler

results.summary_short: “The Wrestler” shows that, in both movies and wrestling, the line between reality and play-acting may be less clear than we assume.

results.headline: A Pop Star in Pursuit of the Primal

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Scott Walker: 30 Century Man

results.summary_short: “Scott Walker: 30 Century Man,” is the story of and oracular singer, experimental composer, British-based American expatriate and reclusive cult figure.

results.headline: Outed Agent and Reporter Go Toe to Toe

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nothing But the Truth

results.summary_short: Despite about a journalist at a powerful newspaper who is jailed for refusing to name her source, “Nothing but the Truth” has nothing to do with you know what or who.

results.headline: Forlorn Husband Makes the Right Moves

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rab Ne Bana Di Jodi

results.summary_short: “Rab Ne Bana di Jodi” deftly blends comedy — the ruling tone of the new Bollywood — with melodrama, the ruling tone of the old.

results.headline: Hope for a Racist, and Maybe a Country

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gran Torino

results.summary_short: “Gran Torino” shows an urgent engagement with the tougher, messier, bigger questions of American life.

results.headline: Trapped in South Boston: Tough Guys

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What Doesn't Kill You

results.summary_short: This film tells a good story well, and in the process quietly says a little something about what it means to look at the American dream from the bottom up.

results.headline: Time Marches Backward, Determination Forward

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Timecrimes

results.summary_short: Proof positive that a naked hottie and whiz-bang pacing can disguise gaping narrative cracks, “Timecrimes” makes sci-fi lemonade out of low-budget lemons.

results.headline: The Geometry of Desire, and the Hunt

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the City of Sylvia

results.summary_short: The writer and director José Luis Guerin has neatly captured the sweet, erotic alienation of being a single man at his leisure in a foreign town, dazzled by the passing procession of local beauties.

results.headline: At Christmas, Seeking Shelter From the Storm

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Where God Left His Shoes

results.summary_short: “Where God Left His Shoes” is a queasy-making drama about a homeless New York family seeking shelter on a snowy Christmas Eve.

results.headline: Murder by the Letter

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Alphabet Killer

results.summary_short: “The Alphabet Killer” is classed up by a director (Rob Schmidt) more interested in facts than in frights.

results.headline: Kim Basinger, Pursued on All Fronts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of While She Was Out

results.summary_short: This cretinous thriller with revenge-fantasy undertones casts a stringy Kim Basinger as a suburban housewife who ends up fighting for her life.

results.headline: It’s All Over, Earthlings (Don’t Flee to New Jersey)
results.display_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Day the Earth Stood Still

results.summary_short: In “The Day the Earth Stood Still,” the alien Klaatu has a mission: to help exterminate the human race.

results.headline: Seasonal Sentiment With Latin Flavoring

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nothing Like the Holidays

results.summary_short: “Nothing Like the Holidays” is an efficient home-for-Christmas ensemble comedy trimmed with plastic teardrops.

results.headline: Between Heaven and Earth, Room for Ambiguity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Doubt

results.summary_short: The air is thick with paranoia in “Doubt,” but nowhere as thick, juicy, sustained or sustaining as Meryl Streep’s performance.

results.headline: Something Rotten in the State of Jhamora (Ask Freddie Prinze Jr.)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delgo

results.summary_short: This barely animated love story suffers from more than just a lack of originality. Dreary battles and apathetic voice work conspire in a sedition-oriented plot that not even six writers are able to invigorate.

results.headline: A Moody Musical

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dark Streets

results.summary_short: “Dark Streets” has atmosphere coming out its ears, but not much going on between them.

results.headline: Saluting the Rebel Underneath the T-Shirt

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Che: Part Two

results.summary_short: Nearly four and a half hours long, spanning more than a decade and reconstructing a pair of brutal insurgencies, “Che” surely deserves the name of epic.

results.headline: Treated Like a Dog, in War and Madness

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adam Resurrected

results.summary_short: Jeff Goldblum’s tour-de-force performance is not enough to transmit a steady emotional current through “Adam Resurrected.”

results.headline: This (New) American Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wendy and Lucy

results.summary_short: “Wendy and Lucy” takes place mainly outdoors and registers the natural beauty of the Pacific Northwest with unostentatious affection.

results.headline: Innocence Is Lost in Postwar Germany

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Reader

results.summary_short: “The Reader” is a scrupulously tasteful film about an erotic affair that turns to love.
